This supersedes IRM 8.7.10, Technical and Procedural Guidelines - Excise Tax Cases and IRA Adjustments dated October 15, 2014. Incorporated Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0916-0007, Excise Tax Dyed Fuel and Refusal Penalty Cases, which was issued September 19, 2016 into this IRM.

and IRA Adjustments
) This IRM section provides procedures for working Excise Tax cases in the Appeals Division. (
) Purpose: The purpose of this IRM section is to provide guidance to Technical Employees (ATEs) so they can prepare accurate excise tax (
) Audience: The primary users of the IRM section are ATEs working Appeals excise tax cases. (
) Policy Owner: The Appeals Policy Owner for this IRM section is the Case Operations and Support. (
) Program Owner: The Appeals Program Owner of this IRM section is Policy. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Appeals Processing and Support (APS), Counsel, SB/SE Specialty Examination, are the primary stakeholders for this IRM section. (

) Appeals may have jurisdiction over any protested excise tax case except alcohol and tobacco taxes under Subtitle E. Some of the more common taxes are covered in this section and include Highway Use Taxes, Chapters through
Excise Taxes, Wagering Excise Taxes, and Excise Taxes on IRA adjustments. (
) Form
, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, is used to report many taxes. The taxes are identiﬁed on Form
by IRS No. (referred to as the abstract number). (
) Form

is due by the last day of the month following the end of the quarter. For ozone depleting chemicals, communications, and air taxes, the return is due by the last day of the second month following the of the quarter. The statutory period for assessment is three years from the date of the return or the date ﬁled, whichever is later. (
) Refer to IRM Exhibit
, Listing of Non-Fuel Excise Taxes Including sociated IRS Sections and Trust Funds, for the most signiﬁcant statutes affecting excise taxes. (

) Appeals will not return cases to Compliance as a premature referral when case is not fully developed. Appeals will attempt to settle a case on factual hazards when the case submitted by Compliance is not fully developed and the taxpayer has presented no new information or evidence. (
) In resolving disputes, the ATE may consider new theories and/or alternative legal arguments that support the parties’ positions when evaluating the hazards of litigation in a case. See IRM
, Taxpayer Raises New Theory or Alternative Legal Argument, for additional information. (
) If a taxpayer raises a new issue, please refer to IRM
, Taxpayer Raises a New Issue. (
) If a taxpayer presents new information, please refer to IRM
, Provides New Information. (
) New case receipts should have at least one year remaining on the period of limitations. Return cases with less than
days remaining on the statute the origination function.

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
If income tax and other taxes are involved, the “kind of tax” portion of the consent form should indicate each type of tax.

For example, one of the issues on a Form 1040 may involve an individual retire- ment account (IRA). The IRA issue may give rise to a Chapter 43 excise tax. If the “kind of tax” line of the consent is completed only for “income tax,” the statutory period for assessing any Chapter 43 excise tax deﬁciency may expire, barring the assessment. Thus, in the above example, the “kind of tax” on the consent form reads “income and Chapter 43”
assessment. Thus, in the above example, the “kind of tax” on the consent form reads “income and Chapter

) Use of Issue Management System (IMS) is mandatory for working Excise cases. Cases carded in to ACDS after
must be worked in IMS in order to give Exam our feedback. The Appeals Centralized Database (ACDS) will remain the Appeals system of record for case management and recording time on cases. (

Additional information on the various roles in IMS and training modules can be found on the Appeals BSP IMS Website, Appeals BSP Website. (

excise tax cases when a mutually satisfactory basis of settlement cannot be reached. Other excise tax cases are not issued a notice of deﬁciency when unagreed because those cases cannot be litigated in Tax Court. (

through IRC

excise tax returns), the return may be prepared by the Service Tax under the authority of IRC

(b) case processing procedures. b. Examination personnel generally use a “substitute for return” with the proposed tax shown as a deﬁciency in the examiner’s report. Note: Cases developed under either method may be protested to Appeals. (

through
) cannot be litigated in Tax Court. Therefore, any unagreed tax (except for the exceptions listed above) is assessed without issuance of a Notice of Deﬁciency. (

is reported on Form
, Heavy Highway Vehicle Use Tax Return. The tax is imposed on a heavy highway vehicle used on public highways and is based on the weight of vehicle. (

and ends the following June
Form is due by the last day of the month following the month during the tax which the vehicle is ﬁrst used on the public highway. (

of each tax period for vehicles in July. The statutory period for assessment is three years from the due date the return or the date ﬁled, whichever is later. (

) There are two excise taxes related to wagering: a. IRC
imposes a tax on wagers as deﬁned in IRC
Form Monthly Tax Return for Wagers, is used to report the tax on wagers. It must be ﬁled every month by the last day of the month following the month in which a taxable wager is accepted. b. IRC
imposes an occupational tax on any person who receives wagers subject to tax under IRC
Form
-C, Occupational Tax Registration Return for Wagering, is used to report the occupational and to register certain information with the IRS. Form
-C must be before a person accepts a taxable wager and annually thereafter, by
, as long as the activity continues. (

at a rate of
percent of the amount of the wager for wagers authorized under the laws of the state in which accepted. other taxable wagers are subject to a rate of

Tax Cases and IRA Adjustments 8.7.10

If the taxpayer does not agree to the changes proposed by Appeals, a statutory notice of deﬁciency cannot be issued. Instead, a report is prepared, the case is closed and the tax is assessed. The taxpayer’s only recourse will be to pay the additional tax when assessed, and ﬁle a claim for refund.
A statutory notice of deﬁciency cannot be issued for unagreed excise taxes related to wagering because notice of deﬁciency procedures only apply to the taxes speciﬁed in IRC
IRC
refers to excise taxes imposed by Chapters
and
of the Internal Revenue Code. IRC
and
) IRC

provides that if: a. any dyed fuel is sold or held for sale by any person for any use which such person knows or has reason to know is not a nontaxable use of fuel; b. any dyed fuel is held for use or used by any person for a use other nontaxable use and such person knew, or had reason to know, that fuel was so dyed; c. any person willfully alters, or attempts to alter, chemically or otherwise, strength or composition of any dye or marking done pursuant to IRC in any dyed fuel; or d. any person who has knowledge that a dyed fuel which has been as described in (c) sells or holds for sale such fuel for any use which person knows or has reason to know is not a nontaxable use of such then such person shall pay a penalty in addition to the tax (if any). (
) The penalty is the greater of $
or $
per gallon of the dyed diesel or dyed kerosene (whether or not the fuel was dyed pursuant to section involved. After the ﬁrst violation, the $

portion of the penalty increases depending on the number of violations. This penalty is in addition to any imposed on the fuel. If the penalty is imposed on any business entity, each officer, employee, or agent of the business entity who willfully participated any act giving rise to the penalty is jointly and severally liable with that for the penalty. (
) Any owner of any building or place, or person having the agency or tendence of the same, who refuses to admit any officer or employee of the Treasury Department acting under the authority of IRC
(relating to the entry of premises for examination of taxable articles) or refuses to permit to examine such article or articles, shall, for every such refusal, forfeit $
(known as the refusal penalty). See IRC
) For further information regarding the dyed diesel fuel penalty see IRM
, Report Writing and Case Processing Overview and IRM Administrative Appeals of Fuel Penalty. (
) Rev. Proc.

provides for an administrative appeal of certain dyed penalties and gives the taxpayer the right to a pre-assessment appeal of proposed dyed diesel and dyed kerosene fuel penalties and the refusal to admit entry for purposes of inspecting facilities and equipment and taking removing samples. (
) See Publication
, Excise Taxes for more information on Dyed Diesel Dyed Kerosene fuels. Internal Revenue Manual

a. any dyed fuel is sold or held for sale by any person for any use which such person knows or has reason to know is not a nontaxable use of fuel; b. any dyed fuel is held for use or used by any person for a use other nontaxable use and such person knew, or had reason to know, that fuel was so dyed; c. any person willfully alters, or attempts to alter, chemically or otherwise, strength or composition of any dye or marking done pursuant to IRC in any dyed fuel; or d. any person who has knowledge that a dyed fuel which has been as described in (c) sells or holds for sale such fuel for any use which person knows or has reason to know is not a nontaxable use of such then such person shall pay a penalty in addition to the tax (if any).

) If the Fuel Compliance Officer (FCO) or the Fuel Compliance Agent (FCA) proposes to assert either the Dyed Fuel Penalty or the Refusal Penalty Appeals the taxpayer, the FCO/FCA will notify the taxpayer in writing. In processing cases to Appeals, excise employees follow guidelines located in IRM Excise Tax - Excise Fuel Compliance Report Writing, Case Processing and Appeals Procedures. (

, Request for an Informal Conference and Appeals Review, and within
days from the date of notiﬁcation to the FCO’s/FCA’s Manager sponsible for the case. (

within
days, Compliance assess the penalty and take appropriate legal action to collect the penalty. (

is submitted within
days, the FCO/FCA Manager sible for the case will contact the taxpayer to arrange a conference. (

days from this date of notiﬁcation to request that the case be reviewed by (

) If a taxpayer does not timely ﬁle a request for an appeal, then the penalty be assessed. If the taxpayer still wants to appeal the penalty, they must pay the penalty in full and ﬁle a claim for refund. (
) Claims are ﬁled using Form
or Form
The full amount of the assessed penalty must be paid before a claim from the taxpayer may be sidered. (
) All issues that remain in dispute between a taxpayer and the IRS involving either the Dyed Diesel Fuel Penalty or the Refusal Penalty are appropriate Appeals an administrative appeal. (
) If there are any questions regarding the statute of limitations on this contact Counsel. (

) With respect to the Dyed Fuel Penalty, issues in dispute may include: a. The fuel involved in an alleged violation was dyed b. The taxpayer knew or had reason to know that the fuel was sold or for sale for other than a non-taxable use (in a case involving IRC
)). c. The taxpayer knew or had reason to know that the fuel was dyed (in a case involving IRC
)). d. The taxpayer acted willfully (in a case involving IRC
)). e. The officer, employee, or agent of a business entity willfully any act giving rise to the Dyed Fuel Penalty under IRC
(d). f. The IRS correctly determined the amount of fuel subject to the Dyed Penalty.

violation if the person has been penalized under this section at least twice after
The person may still ﬁle an appeal, but only limited to the • fraud or mistakes in the chemical analysis, or • a mathematical calculation of the amount of the penalty. (

) Since Appeals jurisdiction and consideration will be afforded to the taxpayer before the ﬁnal determination of the penalty, collection activity will be suspended until Appeals has determined the penalty amount. (

) There is no formal closing letter for these types of cases on ACDS at this Information in the closing letter may include the following statements: a. We have considered your protest and the evidence and arguments in support of your position against the (insert penalty type here). b. If you would like to challenge our determination in court, you may ﬁle a complaint in the United States District Court or the United States Court Federal Claims. If you decide to do this, you must ﬁrst pay the amount owed and ﬁle a claim for refund of the tax. Once the claim for refund is denied or six months have elapsed without any action by the Service, may initiate suit. (

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
There is no formal closing letter for these types of cases on ACDS at this time. Information in the closing letter may include the following statements:

a. We have considered your protest and the evidence and arguments in support of your position against the (insert penalty type here). b. If you would like to challenge our determination in court, you may ﬁle a complaint in the United States District Court or the United States Court of Federal Claims. If you decide to do this, you must ﬁrst pay the amount owed and ﬁle a claim for refund of the tax. Once the claim for refund is denied or six months have elapsed without any action by the Service, you may initiate suit.

) The Internal Revenue Code deﬁnes, in some instances generally and in others in speciﬁc terms, the conditions under which interest is either restricted or pro- hibited on Internal Revenue taxes. The table below lists the sections of the Internal Revenue Code and certain provisions having the effect of law, which govern adjustments resulting in deﬁciencies or overassessments on which interest is restricted in excise tax cases. It also lists an identifying title and the related provision which governs the computation of interest.
